oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Simulated airborne spread of Aujeszky's disease and foot-and-mouth disease
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Casal, J.
Moreso, J. M.
Planas-Cuch√≠, E.
Casal, J.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: virus spread
foot-and-mouth
Aujeszky's disease
computer model
atmospheric dispersion
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The atmospheric dispersion of virus was simulated using a computer model which had been developed for predicting the dispersion of toxic gases from chemical engineering plants. The results were compared with data from four outbreaks in which virus was believed to have been transported by air: two outbreaks of foot-and-mouth disease in the United Kingdom in 1967 and outbreaks of Aujeszky's disease in Yorkshire in 1981 to 1982 and Indiana in 1988. There was relatively good agreement with most of these data. The paper shows that the model could be useful in an emergency because the risk of virus spread could be predicted in real time. Full paper published in Veterinary Record (1997) 140, 672-676
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 1997; 4
